Sperm Evolution in Tardigrades
Project
Using both comparative and experimental approaches, I investigate the evolutionary causes and consequences of sperm form and function variation in a group where both sperm and mating biology have unparalleled diversity — the tardigrades.
View
  • 2 Updates
Tardigrade biodiversity in Central Africa
Project
The aim of this project is a comprehensive integrative taxonomic analysis of African tardigrades from Kenya, Tanzania and Ethiopia. Tardigrades (water bears) are globally distributed macroinvertebrates with a worldwide distribution and are known for their ability to survive in extreme environments. The first studies on tardigrades in Africa were conducted over a century ago but still the African tardigrade fauna is poorly known with only ca. 160 species reported from this continent so far. In contrast, a similar number of tardigrade taxa have been listed from countries/areas of much smaller territories, e.g. Poland (ca. 100), Hungary (ca. 120), or Costa Rica (ca. 100). This suggests that the biodiversity of African tardigrades is grossly underestimated. The tardigrade taxonomy faces identification/differentiation problems due to small numbers of taxonomically meaningful morphological characters. Moreover, many of the original species descriptions are old and therefore contain very poor quality and inaccurate information. That is why, comparative studies on tardigrade morphology and morphometry as well as molecular data are needed in order to estimate biodiversity in this phylum. Realisation of the project would greatly deepen our knowledge on the tardigrade fauna of Africa and could also shed light on the currently unresolved phylogenetic relationships between some taxa. The project was partially supported by the by the Foundation for Polish Science via the 'Homing Plus' programme (grant no. HP/2012-5/8 awarded to Łukasz Michalczyk), by the European Commission’s programme “Transnational Access to Major Research Infrastructures” to SYNTHESYS (grant no. DK-TAF- 5609 “Revision of the central African tardigrade fauna” to Daniel Stec), and by the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education via the Iuventus Plus programme (grant no. IP2014 017973 to Łukasz Kaczmarek). So far, we described three new species (one is published, one is accepted, and one is currently under review) and redescriptions of two further taxa are in preparation. The project is ongoing, we are planning to obtain new moss and lichen samples from Tanzania and Ethiopia this year curtesy of our collaborators and friends from the University of Copenhagen.

Annotated zoogeography of non-marine Tardigrada
Project
The aim of the project is to summarise and review all literature records of limno-terrestrial water bears (Tardigrada). We have been publishing the results in a series of Zootaxa monographs. Each part describes an updated and revised tardigrade taxonomy that is accompanied by geographic co-ordinates, habitat, and biogeographic comments for a given geographic region (typically a continent). It is hoped this work will serve as a reference point and background for further zoogeographical and taxonomical studies.
